nodes.bodyText: required explicitly enumerating the maps in data() above
This was the bug in #3131 - also needed to check for domainToDomainId
This is not my dark magic - it's a copy-paste.

Can you generify it so that it takes in either a type parameter or argument for the enum class to be harvested?
I'd like to see some more comments on why it has to be copied and what each chunk is doing.

Can you make an identifier for null in this case, like STATIC?
I'm confused about what e is here. Maybe enumEntry or enumVal would help.

This might be a place where making a local lambda makes things cleaner. E.g. Function<Short, enumClass> fromStorage = storageValue -> fromStorage.invoke(null, storageValue); The invoke null takes a while to get used to.
How do we test the reverse direction? I.e. how do we know we don't have shorts written to the db someplace that don't map back to an enum value?
I guess by virtue of them being in a bimap it's not a problem, but the test shouldn't know that.
Maybe this is really getFirstParameterType()?
"strongly"?
no, it's typed as a string
This is a sign that we're trying too hard I think.

This test is extremely tightly tied to the implementation of the class. Ideally we capture enough of the functionality that migrating to something cleaner is easier. If we hold on too tightly, this could actually slow us down a bit.
Can we name this enumClassToToStorageMethod?
Is it worth even fiddling with common-api if it's about to get reabsorbed?

nodes.bodyText: I really feel like this test knows too much about the implementation. I should ideally be able to go in and change out how we map things and the test cases should still pass if I've done it correctly. If the test expects biMap, that won't be true.
nit: Iterables.concat might be easier, but this is fine
These are old-school [ ] arrays so concat can't handle them
nit:  looks like this comment got detached
nit: I'd put v on the right, since it's the known quantity and not the experimental quantity.
ok
nit: might be easier to read if you break it into the method lookup and invocation.
ok
nit: you might (later) also look for bimaps that don't have these properties and make noise, but I think it's ok.
nit: ordinarily I don't expect statements with side effects inside a map call. It's OK here.
